intro: Sisymbrium lyratum, commonly known as the sweet rocket, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender stems and alternate, oval-shaped leaves. Its flowers, which are usually pink or purple, bloom in early summer and attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Sisymbrium lyratum is often found in meadows, wastelands, and along roadsides, thriving in full sun to partial shade.
